Co-designing a democratic knowledge platform to aid action in the water sector.

INREM foundation is an NGO working in the water quality sector in India. To aid the transfer of ideas, knowledge and learnings, amongst the various actors in this sector, they identified the need for a ‘knowledge platform’. It was in this context that we came in— to help better define the ‘platform’, and then to build it.

Go straight to outcomes

Defining the Scope

Due to a pre-existing work relationship, We were uniquely placed, to have the ‘going to be’ beneficiaries of the ‘going to be’ platform, define what it should even be in the first place.

So that’s how we planned the project— to workshop intensively with the beneficiaries— translate the outcomes into a product, at the earliest— put it back in their hands— and then slowly iterate on it based on their invaluable feedback.

Duration
5 months (Nov ’18 - Mar ’19 : ongoing)
Client
INREM Foundation
Role
Strategy . Product Management . UX . Web Development
Core Team
Abrar . Sheneille . Akshay

Process

Project Kick off
Our first exposure to the water quality sector happened at the Fluoride Network Meet. After which, we workshopped with a varied set of players, to map out the various actors and their relationships in this sector. Certain recurring archetypes started to emerge.

Defining the Knowledge Platform
Many types of 'knowledge' in various shapes and forms were explored, but one particularly stood out— the invaluable stories from the ground, that tend to get lost in the chaos of bureaucracy.

The question that we found ourselves thinking about was, how can the platform ‘guide’ such content contributors, to tell more compelling stories? In the months to come, this question grew into the idea of 'storytelling templates'.

How can the platform ‘guide’ content contributors, to tell more compelling stories?

The Actual Build - Platform version 0.1
'Contributing content' was chosen as the priority use case as we stepped into build mode. Our product design & development philosophy was grounded in the analogy— first build a skateboard, then a bicycle, and only then, the car.

As a 2 person ‘product team’ having experience working with each other,we tried to stay lean. At times we would jump directly from wireframes to code, and on other occasions, sketch out high fidelity screen designs when trying to comprehend & explore more complex use cases.

Our product design & development philosophy was grounded in the analogy— first build a skateboard, then a bicycle, and only then, the car.

Testing knowledge platform 0.1
We got together with some of our end users, that we had workshopped with initially, and put platform 0.1 in their hands.

One of the key insights that came out from this activity was that, our ‘storytelling template’ was viewed as a helpful assistant, but too prescriptive at times.

Our ‘storytelling template’ was viewed as a helpful assistant, but too prescriptive at times.

Building version 0.2: Diving into details
How can we create a guided template that is flexible enough to accommodate for the non-linear nature of stories? How can we ‘hint’ uses to elaborate on certain key elements of a story, such as— context, characters, events, outcomes etc— rather than enforcing a linear order of these elements? Platform 0.2 was built atop these questions

Outcomes So Far

Version 0.2.1 of the platform, is currently live on the URL— waterquality.network/stories. Its evolving and transforming continuously, with refinments and updates being pushed out every week.

Below, you can see some of the screens of knowledge platform 0.2, as they stand, at the time of writing this piece.

Highlights

Participatory Design
We co-designed the platform with many of the folks who are currently using it. And we plan to continue doing so.

Lean design and development was hard, making it a great learning.
I realize now why they say it takes a team that is experienced with agile methods, to pull off agile efficiently. But this was a good start for us!

Challenges Faced

Limited funds for this project meant that we couldn’t put together a dedicated full-time team for it. This made the process relatively slower than what could have been. It also meant multitasking and taking on tasks that aren't a part of your primary skillset. For me that was web-development (but I can't say I didn't enjoy it).

Current Status & Roadmap Ahead

Stories have been trickling onto the platform, and so has feedback. New insights are turning into new updates on the platform quite regularly.

Other than going deeper and cracking the idea of the story-telling templates, we are working on adding content types like data stories and tutorials. Also, down the road, the idea is to introduce a ‘composite content type’, wherein, users can combine tutorials, stories, data & more, into a single powerful piece.
